docs.snippet: Larry Burdick, a chocolatier known for his tiny ganache-filled chocolate mice with silk tails, has added little bunnies to his menagerie. They are covered with white chocolate, have almond ears and are more delectably engaging than any egg-shaped ...
docs.abstract: Comment on Easter candies made by chocolatier Larry Burdick; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Larry Burdick, a chocolatier known for his tiny ganache-filled chocolate mice with silk tails, has added little bunnies to his menagerie. They are covered with white chocolate, have almond ears and are more delectably engaging than any egg-shaped truffle in the Easter basket. They are $2.99 each at Citarella, and $15 for a box of six from www.burdickchocolate.com or (800) 229-2419, and, starting Friday, at Two for the Pot in Brooklyn Heights.

headline.main: When Chocolate Flowers Bloom, It Must Be Spring

docs.snippet: A cloud of zabaglione is lovely to spoon over strawberries or a fruit compote and makes a great Passover dessert. At Shallots NY, a kosher restaurant at 550 Madison Avenue (55th Street), the chef, Damian Sansonetti, beats 4 egg yolks with 2 tables...
docs.abstract: Comment on zabaglione served at Shallots NY, kosher restaurant on Madison Avenue; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A cloud of zabaglione is lovely to spoon over strawberries or a fruit compote and makes a great Passover dessert. At Shallots NY, a kosher restaurant at 550 Madison Avenue (55th Street), the chef, Damian Sansonetti, beats 4 egg yolks with 2 tablespoons superfine sugar and 1/4 cup of kosher Italian moscato, a delicately sweet wine. He places the bowl over a pot of simmering water and whisks the mixture, adding another 1/4 cup of the wine, for about 10 minutes, until soft peaks form. The zabaglione can be held for more than an hour if a scant teaspoon of potato starch is mixed with the sugar. For children, white grape juice can replace the wine. Serve layered with fruit in four pretty glasses or dessert dishes. Passover meringues would make an excellent accompaniment; Shallots NY sells them and other baked goods. Orders can be placed at www.shallotsny.com.

headline.main: It's as Light as Air, but Tastier

docs.snippet: Viking, whose professional-style ranges are considered by many to be the Rolls-Royces of the home kitchen, has opened a culinary center in Garden City, N.Y., at 835 Franklin Avenue. There is a kitchen for hands-on cooking classes (below, teaching,...
docs.abstract: Viking, maker of professional-style ranges, opens culinary center in Garden City, NY, where cooking demonstrations and classes will be offered; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Viking, whose professional-style ranges are considered by many to be the Rolls-Royces of the home kitchen, has opened a culinary center in Garden City, N.Y., at 835 Franklin Avenue. There is a kitchen for hands-on cooking classes (below, teaching, is Daniel Orr of Guastavino's), a 40-seat theater for cooking demonstrations, a shop and, of course, a showroom stocked with Viking appliances. The excellent shop, left, has bakeware, gadgets and utensils, cutlery and pots (including brands other than Viking's own), plus tableware, glassware, condiments and spices. For a schedule of cooking classes: (516) 877-1010 or www.vikingrange.com.

headline.main: What to Do With What You Bought

docs.snippet: When Elspeth Treadwell worked in an office, she often treated co-workers and friends to her cupcakes and other baked goods. The day she saw a little storefront for rent at 231 East Fifth Street (Bowery), she decided to switch careers. She named he...
docs.abstract: Elspeth Treadwell sells her baked goods at Podunk, store on Lower East Side; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Elspeth Treadwell worked in an office, she often treated co-workers and friends to her cupcakes and other baked goods. The day she saw a little storefront for rent at 231 East Fifth Street (Bowery), she decided to switch careers. She named her store Podunk, and now sells buttery cookies (75 cents each), scones (75 cents and $1.25), cupcakes ($1.50 each) and cardamom and vanilla Bundt cakes (by the slice or $22 to $24 for the whole cake). She offers various tea menus ($8 to $16 for one person, $14 to $30 for two). The room is furnished with used furniture and knickknacks, all for sale.

headline.main: Podunk, by Way of the Bowery, for Sweets

docs.snippet: Cast iron, that old-fashioned kitchen workhorse, has always needed seasoning; that is, a light oiling and heating to seal the porous metal surface. Or, as Lodge Manufacturing in South Pittsburg, Tenn., the country's top maker of cast-iron cookware...
docs.abstract: Lodge Manufacturing introduces line of preseasoned cast-iron cookware; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Cast iron, that old-fashioned kitchen workhorse, has always needed seasoning; that is, a light oiling and heating to seal the porous metal surface. Or, as Lodge Manufacturing in South Pittsburg, Tenn., the country's top maker of cast-iron cookware, put it, ''until cooking countless batches of fried chicken, catfish and crispy crusted corn bread burnished it to a treasured black patina.''

headline.main: So That Catfish Doesn't Have to Wait

docs.snippet: Marina Borges, right, is in holiday overdrive, which is quite natural this time of year for a cookie baker. Her specialties are cunning star-shaped linzers, buttery snickerdoodles, fragile chocolate-rimmed leaves, and intense chocolate cookies tha...
docs.abstract: Marina Borges is busy filling holiday orders for her sumptuous cookies; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Marina Borges, right, is in holiday overdrive, which is quite natural this time of year for a cookie baker. Her specialties are cunning star-shaped linzers, buttery snickerdoodles, fragile chocolate-rimmed leaves, and intense chocolate cookies that sparkle with sugar, among a dozen or so varieties. She also bakes savories like cheese-corn madeleines to serve as hors d'oeuvres.

headline.main: Baking Up A Blizzard Of Cookies

docs.snippet: Chocolate treats fill the display case at Lunchbox Food Company, 357 West Street (Clarkson Street) in Greenwich Village. Jennifer Kohns, above center, and Lawrence Rudolph, right, have turned what was a diner into a kitchen, restaurant and shop wi...
docs.abstract: Halloween candy and cookies can appeal to adult taste; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Chocolate treats fill the display case at Lunchbox Food Company, 357 West Street (Clarkson Street) in Greenwich Village. Jennifer Kohns, above center, and Lawrence Rudolph, right, have turned what was a diner into a kitchen, restaurant and shop with chocolate brown furnishings. There are three kinds of chocolate: dark, white and chili-spiced Mexican with a hint of cinnamon.

headline.main: Wave of Chocolate Transforms a Village Diner

docs.snippet: Dried sausages made in France are now being sold in the United States for the first time, having passed stringent government inspections. The Jean de France line of saucissons, made in Lyon, has a garlicky complexity enhanced by flavorings like wi...
docs.abstract: Dried sausages made in France are sold in US for first time, having passed stringent government inspection; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Dried sausages made in France are now being sold in the United States for the first time, having passed stringent government inspections. The Jean de France line of saucissons, made in Lyon, has a garlicky complexity enhanced by flavorings like wine, nuts or peppercorns. Whole 10-ounce sausages are about $8 at Citarella stores, Dean & DeLuca, Zabar's, Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory. There is also a plain, slow-aged traditional version called Rosette de Lyon, and one flavored with Beaujolais, sliced, each for about $12 a pound.

headline.main: U.S. Says Oui, and France Sends Sausages to These Shores

docs.snippet: Chocolat Bla Bla Bla is tucked alongside a beauty salon at 359 East 50th Street, sharing the entry. But Lorraine Belmont, above, a caterer who said she ''had to open a chocolate shop'' after seeing the film ''Chocolat,'' said that somehow, custome...
docs.abstract: Lorraine Belmont opens chocolate shop in Manhattan's East Side called Chocolat Bla Bla Bla; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Chocolat Bla Bla Bla is tucked alongside a beauty salon at 359 East 50th Street, sharing the entry. But Lorraine Belmont, above, a caterer who said she ''had to open a chocolate shop'' after seeing the film ''Chocolat,'' said that somehow, customers never seem to mistake one store for the other. ''People manage to find anything chocolate,'' she said. Her cluttered little shop has everything from gimmicky chocolate fusilli to serious truffles, fine dark chocolate bars and baking tablets by Michel Cluizel from France and flavored chocolate bars from Café-Tasse from Belgium.

headline.main: Finding the Chocolate Shop, And No Road Map Is Needed
